results.title: Abortion: a tale of two cities
results.brief_description: Uses two dramatised case studies to highlight some of the problems faced by different sections of the community, in the provision of abortion. Intended for women’s groups and for people concerned with health education. Cast includes: Judy Snape, Marlene Sidaway, Max Smith, Derry Jordan, Fred Grant. Narrated by Peter Ellis.

results.title: Aborigines of the Northern Territory: scouting outpost
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Bob Kingsbury and Cinesound Movietone
results.brief_description: Scouting has become an important activity among young Aboriginal children of Maningrida on the Arafura Sea in Northern Australia. In 1964 a school teacher introduced scouting, and its popularity led to the growth of the movement to include Cubs, Rovers and Guides. Young people from eleven tribes in the area are involved.

results.title: Aboriginal legends. No. 3
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson, Educational Media Australia and David Corke
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal legends gathered from tribal elders by student teachers from Kormilda College, Darwin are retold with accompanying illustrations by the students. The titles include: “Why the Emu cannot fly” - storyteller and artist, Nugget Jabangadi James; “Inganarr, the giant Serpent” - story by Bunug, artist Nathanael Maralngura; “The Bat and the Rainbow” - story by Anastasia Kelantumana, artist Suzanne Chalmers. These stories and pictures can be found in the book entitled “Djugurba”. Narrated by Juliana Allan, Wynne Nelson and Peter Gwynne.

results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson, Educational Media Australia and David Corke
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal legends gathered from Tribal elders by student teachers from Kormilda College, Darwin are retold with accompanying illustrations by the students. results.title: Aboriginal fibre crafts of Aurukun
results.brief_description: The traditional fibre crafts of the Aboriginal women of Aurukun are demonstrated by Annie Kalkeeyorta and Neeyum Yunkaporta, from the collection and spinning of the fibres through to the varieties of finished products. Narrated by Jane Harders.

results.title: Aboriginal Family Education Centre: Alexandria 1972
results.brief_description: A record of the Van Leewin project’s Aboriginal Family Education Centre in Redfern, Sydney. Parents learn with their children, mothers record the children’s activities with video. Differences between black and white cultural values are articulated and clarified.

results.title: Aboriginal art: conserving, exhibiting, interpreting
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
In recent decades Aboriginal art has increasingly been destined for art museums and major private collections. It has not been totally subsumed into the Western art dealer and museum system, but has made curators and art historians ask some profound questions about their practices and policies of collecting and exhibiting art. One concern is the involvement of non- Aboriginal curators and art advisers, with many believing they occupy positions which would be more appropriately held by Aboriginal people. Curators Djon Mundine, Wally Caruana and Peter Sutton discuss gallery collecting policies, major exhibitions and key issues in the criticism of contemporary Aboriginal art.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service

results.title: Abnormal behavior: a mental hospital (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Tom Lazarus, CRM Productions and Neil Reichline
results.brief_description: A series of doctor-patient interviews acquaint the viewer with the symptomatology of various types of schizophrenic disturbances. In an unusual sequence, a patient with paranoid tendencies is shown undergoing electro-convulsive therapy. The director of the hospital tells of the hospital’s goals in this and other forms of treatment.

results.title: Ablutions
results.brief_description: Ablutions is an interactive journey where the user controls the fate of a character in a world that consumes technology. Through exploring the narrative the user partakes in the experience of cleansing the self from everyday technology and its commodities; questioning the nature of our identity. By doing this, freedom is redefined. Once cleansed, the character recovers the lost items, discovering their meaning and importance.
